title.narrative: Imp. of Plan of Southern Egypt

description.narrative: The project focuses on strengthening local administrations and building capacities on planning for sustainable human settlements, especially in strategic planning and community-based planning.
seat of a first-order administrative division

•Two proposals for institutional development are produced, negotiated with stakeholders and submitted to the competent administrative autorities(CAAs) concerning secure land tenure in Farfara and coordinated investment promotion in the New Assiut.
•Two institutional anchors for participatory planning and management of human settlements are created and/or strengthened.

comment.narrative:
1. GOPP and local partners in southern Egypt introduced to participatory approaches but yet to adopt them on regular basis with in-house capacity and enabling organizational set-ups.
2. Local partners unfamiliar with participatory planning, institutional barriers cause investment growth to slow down and put livelihoods at risk.
3. Coordination between investment policies and mechanisms in Assiut governorate and New Assiut city is very limited. Barriers to private sector development cause slow growth and capital flight.

- Finalization of Projects: West Asyut, City of Al-Tod, Luxor, image of Hurghada, Red Sea, and approval of the development plans for the City of Halayeb, Red Sea. - Phase 2 of preparing plans for the West of Asyut, strategic plan for El-Tod, Luxor, detailed plans for Al-Bawaiti, Bahariya Oasis and Port Fouad completed, - Phase 3 of preparing plans for the West of Asyut, strategic plan for El-Tod, Luxor, detailed plans for Al-Bawaiti, Bahariya Oasis and Port Fouad completed, - Profiles for Bani Suwayf, Port Said and Port Fouad, Shebin El-Kom concluded after stakeholders discussions. - States of Egyptian Cities report started.
- Profile studies of the City of Tod and Luxor completed. - Profile studies Port Said, Port Fouad, Bani Suwayf, and Shebin El-Kom were prepared.

description.narrative: Bioenergy technology is widely used in at least four rural governorates.

comment.narrative: Bioenergy technology not widely accepted in rural areas.

An increase number of biogas households established and functioning. The BDF is established and functioning to ensure sustainability of the project. At least one commercial biogas unit is established. A number of community units established.

More than 200 household biogas have been installed since Jan 2016 either by the legally registered BSPs of trained engineers and masons or through training. 15 groups, each consisting of one engineer and one mason, have participated in 50-day on-job training on building, curing, connecting and maintaining the household biogas units. - Another commercial biogas unit (50M3/day) in Behera in one of the big cattle farm. It is a German design and similar to the Indian design applied in the household units. It is installed by project masons under the supervision of projects engineers and used to train two BSPs. The installed commercial unit is now producing gas and bio fertilizer. 63 community units that each serves three households. The units have been functioning well for almost 6 months.- A new financial mechanism for financing biogas units either the household units or commercial biogas units has been studies and will be implanted by the new Association and a commercial bank. - A Decree from The Board of Governorates headed by the Prime Minister which states that all governors should work jointly with the Ministry of Environment and the Ministry of Local Development in promoting the take-up of biogas units in all Egypt. Also the other decree from Cabinet of Ministries which approve the establishment of the Bioenergy Association to continue all the activity of the project after its end. Both of them are the main enabling policy framework for promoting sustainable rural biomass energy in Egypt.- The Bioenergy for Sustainable Rural Development Association as a centralized association representing legal entities has been established and the board of the association consist of 11 members of different ministries, authorities and the civil society. The Association is headed by the Minster of the Environment of the PSC. The Association will continuing the bioenergy market promotion after the project and its funding secured.
Project completed.
Project successfully closed.

description.narrative: Mainstreaming Groundwater Considerations into the Integrated Management of the Nile River Basin

title.narrative: TERMINAL EVALUATION OF THE MAINSTREAMING GROUNDWATER CONSIDERATIONS INTO THE INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF THE NILE RIVER BASIN

description.narrative: The scientific basis and necessary institutional and policy support for incorporating a groundwater dimension into planning and management of the Nile basin ecosystem is provided
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

- Identification and adoption of a mechanism (specialist panel, GW specialist network) to sustain the inclusion of GW considerations in NBI processes - Enhanced mainstreaming of GW consideration in national level water resource management

comment.narrative: Groundwater considerations are not included in the Nile basin water resources planning and management
Final project workshop organized
Final project workshop organized

description.narrative: Goal The development objective of the project is to provide the scientific basis and necessary institutional and policy support for incorporating a groundwater dimension into planning and management of the Nile basin ecosystem as an essential component of sustainable development of the Nile Basin Objectives a Improve the assessment of groundwatersurface water interactions towards strengthening protection of key ecosystem resources as well as the gains from and losses to groundwater on rivers and lakes in the Nile basin b Enhance the characterization of the role of groundwater in wetlands and of the Sudd Swamps in the regional water cycle c Improve the use of water balance models in estimating basinwide annual and monthly water balances in the Nile basin as an input to water planning and management d Facilitate the inclusion of groundwater considerations into integrated Nile basin water resources planning and management activities and ensure a common understanding of groundwater issues and analysis among the riparian countries

1Identification and adoption of a mechanism specialist panel GW specialist network to sustain the inclusion of GW considerations in NBI processes
2 Enhanced mainstreaming of groundwater consideration in national level water resource management

comment.narrative: Groundwater is overlooked in the regional water resource planning
Groundwater resources in the Nile river system are adequately assessed managed and integrated into water resource planning

The services of four regional experts were hired to work with the counterparts to analyse the isotopic and chemical data generated under the project update the national reports and prepare Nile subbasin reports including a summary report The services of an international expert were hired to get prepared a reportchapter on the water balance model developed with test runs The services of two additional international experts were hired to assist the counterpart and regional experts to finalise and review the national and subbasin reports including Nile Basin summary report The all tasks have been completed successfully
Following are the main observations and technical achievements
1 Several segments of the Nile course along which surface watergroundwater interaction is or is not taking place have been identified The area of influence of the Nile on adjacent aquifers is estimated in selected segments Amounts of Nile water flowing to adjacent aquifers have been estimated by modeling approach and this has been confirmed by isotope hydrology application
2 Results of this study indicate that swamps in the Equatorial Lakes region may in fact be fed by groundwater However due to several challenges related to security issues the Sudd swamps studies could not be accomplished and Sudd hydrology could not be ascertained despite of the great socioeconomic environmental and hydrological importance of the Sudd wetland
3 Isotope hydrology data gathered under this project have been utilized in the modelling work to validate the model results in two subbasins where this work was done The model is intended to be integrated into the Nile Decision Support System hosted at the Nile Basin Initiative
4 Active involvement of counterparts from all the countries in all the aspects of the project including capacity building as well as involvement of the Nile Basin Initiative and its governance structures to approve the project outputs has been key in ensuring a common understanding of groundwater issues and analysis among the riparian countries as well as facilitating the inclusion of groundwater considerations into integrated Nile basin water resources planning and management activities

One new protocol between EEAA, NREA and EETC established..

The MSB project lead the consortium between EEAA, NREA(New and Renewable Ebergy Authority), EETC (Egyptian Electricity transefere company) and RCREEE (Regional Center for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency) during the developing the protocol between all parties regarding the management of 26 wind farm projects at the Gulf of Suez. The protocol was signed on Dec. 2015 and activated from the spring migration season, 2016. This protocol was the base line to conduct a strategic Environmental Impact Assessment SEIA to 255 km2 for 2 seasons (Spring and Autumn, 2016) in what is called Feed –in-Tariff projects to identify, high risky, risky and non risky areas. The project participated actively in developing the TORs, Selection process of the consultant, and negotiation with the consultant about the work methodology, work Plans and reviewing reports for both spring and autumn migrations 2016. The project with a team from EEAA visited the site three times this year to make sure that the methodology applied in satisfied manner.

- National Strategic Plan methodology for developing land use plans for growth corridors prepared. - Regional strategic guidelines (printouts, CDs and website) in place. - Strategic Plan for Suez Canal Economic Region prepared and available for implementation. - Strategic Plan for North Upper Egypt Economic Region prepared and available for implementation. - A regional/governorate strategic guidelines document in place - Five Strategic Governorate Plans in Suez Canal Region prepared and available for implementation. - Two Strategic Governorate Plans in North Upper Egypt Region prepared and available for implementation - Action plans for Zifta and Awlad Sakr prepared. - The information management policies are implemented. - A full network and data exchange system is running between RPPC number 3 and local authorities

comment.narrative: - There is an Egyptian National 2017 Spatial Plan but it does not include a long term vision or strategies to address issues related to urban growth and expansions in a holistic approach. - The problem of uncontrolled population growth and encroachment of conurbations on agricultural land is increasing. It currently presents a serious challenge to development and social prosperity. - Opportunities for urban development and growth exist but have not been incorporated into planning. - Lack of strategic plans on the regional level. - Applied planning methods are not documented and depend mainly on individual experiences. - A gap exists between planning at the national level (socio-economic national plans) and the local levels (city and village planning). The result is usually an inefficient interrelationship between planning objectives and strategies at both levels. - Lack of strategic plans on the governorate level. - Applied planning methods are not documented and depend mainly on individual experiences. - A gap exists between planning at the national level (socio-economic national plans) and the local levels (city and village planning). The result is an inefficient connection between planning objectives and strategies at both levels. - All seven regional centers are currently connected and networked with GOPP headquarters but the connection is not yet utilized. - Several policies and guidelines related to data standardization and information management are currently available. However they have not been fully implemented. - RPPCs and local authority's staff are characterized by low capacity in working within computer-based networked environment, and lack experience in using corporate GIS techniques. - Follow-up of plans is only on the financial aspects or economic plans – spatial plans have almost no examples of follow-up, let alone evaluation.

- A National Conference to present the spatial vision to stakeholders carried out. The vision refined and presented to the Prime Minister. - GIS enterprise network established, a training system (including capacity building in GIS enterprise) is running (at least 20 staff members are trained each year) - Strategic Governorate Plans for the Sinai Governorates launched (including a possible new governorate in mid Sinai)
- GIS enterprise network established - Strategic Governorate Plans for the Sinai Governorates launched

description.narrative: At project end, achieved levels of revenue are within 10% of projection and the trend in growth rates sets the NCS on track to meet the optimal scenario.

comment.narrative: Financing of protected areas is below 20% of basic scenario.

Assist NCS to have financial plans for at least 8 PAs. Capacity building for NCS staff to help better have financial plans in place. At least two integrated management system prepared. commercial services plans development for at least two PAs.

• Capacity building for the Biodiversity Economics Unit at Nature Conservation Sector (NCS) to effectively conduct economic evaluation and to manage commercial activities and attract investment. • Assisting NCS to have clear financial plans for each PA of the targets, even more, this plans now automatically integrated into the main financial plan for the whole PAs network. • Implemented of a set of comprehensive trainings and training workshops which have contributed to the improvement of the staff capacity to a better understanding of system planning and financial management systems, as well as financial audit and how to prepare financial reports. All these training have implemented within the main framework of PAs management system. • Two integrated management systems were prepared for (Wadi Degla and White Desert protectorates) in the framework of the program of “development of integrated management systems for PAs in Egypt”, bringing the total plans that have been developed to 10 management plans include all eight targeted PAs. • Within the framework of the revenue generation programs, commercial services plans have been developed for Wadi Degla and Wadi El-Rayan PAs where 10 opportunities for investment are available at these PAs, the total revenues is estimated at about 12 million dollars over ten years. In addition to the provision of fixed assets and infrastructure of about 5 million dollars and providing nearly 600 job opportunity for members of the local community. • These plans are significant step towards the establishment of clear mechanisms of best ways for conscious investments in PAs, in order to achieve the main goal of conserving natural resources. • Developing the Request for Proposal (RFP) documents for eight economic projects (concessions) to be offered by NCS through the official bidding system as one of the best methods for the PAs resources generation. The RFPs are the legal basis for contracting with any investor that is willing to perfo

According to the official reports on financing of PA system during reporting year, a general indicator shows remarkable progress where $ 3.4m was allocated as a governmental budget and $1.2.m was allocated to PAs as co-sharing for the project toward optimal scenario of PA management. Five management system plans have been submitted to NCS for revision to be adopted and used as legal instruments for managing targeted PAs. An effective program for raising the capacity of PAs infrastructures was initiated where the following activities have been achieved.

A system-level financing strategy has been developed for the protected area system and is currently under implementation. New sources for revenue were proposed across different protected areas. Moreover, 12 new diversified and sustainable sources of funds have been developed including; Wadi El Gemal National Park Visitors Center concession, Wadi El Rayan Climate Change Museum concession, Satayeh Dolphin House revenue generation scheme, Tiwal Island Eco-cafeteria, Om El Sheikh Island Eco-cafeteria, Utoupia Island environmental restaurant. Estimates refer to at least 30% increase in protected areas concessions income as a result of the new revenue generation schemes. There was a remarkable increase in the governmental co-funding in protected areas support that has reached 8,500,000 USD since 2012.

title.narrative: Adaptation to Climate Change in the Nile Delta

description.narrative: Adaptation to Climate Change in the Nile Delta through Integrated Coastal Zone Management

title.narrative: 00057676_Adaptation to CC in the Nile Delta Through ICZM
RFP - Integrated Coastal Zone Management in Egypt
Terminal Evaluation for Climate Change Adaptation in Nile Delta Project

description.narrative: Adaptation to Climate Change in the Nile Delta through Integrated Coastal Zone Management
populated place
seat of a first-order administrative division
seat of a first-order administrative division
seat of a first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Enhanced resilience of Nile Delta Coastal area, on approximately 2,504 km2, due to adaptation measures.

comment.narrative: North coast of Egypt is characterized by high vulnerability to impacts of sea level rise.
Complete construction works of two pilot projects for soft engineering shore protection techniques

Construction of two pilot coastal protection soft engineering solutions were completed including soft dikes and sedimentation basin to receive the sediments from dredging port approach channel to be used for beach nourishment

Test performance of the soft dikes under winter storms and expand the coastal defense system
Initiate implementation of the National Observatory System

The established systems performed very well under the storms. Steering committee decided to extend the use of the dikes system to larger stretches that were constructed in 2017.
Three tide gauges were installed in 2017

description.narrative: Objective to integrate the management of SLR risks into the development of Egypts Low Elevation Coastal Zone LECZ in the Nile Delta
Enhanced resilience of Nile Delta coastal area on approximately 2504 km2 due to adaptation measures eg beach nourishment vegetative buffers sand placement and dune stabilization

comment.narrative: North coasts of Egypt are characterized by high vulnerability to impacts of SLR SLR will inundate land and coastal infrastructure and will also result in seawater intrusion will also further change the offshore water current patterns resulting in beach erosion and change in the shoreline which has its negative impact on tourism SLR will also deteriorate coastal Mediterranean wetlands and induce stress on fisheries in the coastal lagoons Furthermore SLR The government has been investing in hard coastal protective measures that often diminish the robustness of the coast to anticipated SLR

At least three types of resilienceenhancing measures employed by the project upon its completion in each of the three main coastal lagoons Idku Burullus and Manzala coastal lagoons covering 60 of coastal area of concern

Project Management Unit PMU focused on implementing the soft measures in Damiatta and Rosetta to Burullus
In Damiatta several meetings have been held between the Damiatta Port Authority DPA Shore Protection Authority SPA and Coastal Research Institute CoRI A road map was signed on 21 January 2015 detailing the steps that will be undertaken by each organisation to nourish the eroding breaches near Damiatta with the dredged material from the approach channel of the port
For the second pilot site Rosetta to Burullus where a dike application is tested as a means to protect the area and the international Coastal Road The selected site for the pilot is nearly flooded each year at high storms SPA contracted a contractor ARC Marine to construct the dike A site visit was made with the contractors representative Construction will start in July 2015
The PMU also held eight meetings with the project management and executive committees to discuss the progress of the project activities present any obstacles and recommend ways forward These meetings proved to be very useful as many obstacles were overcome and many good recommendations were made
The PMU has also met HE the Minister of Water Resources and Irrigation three times The first meeting was as part of MWRI Climate Change Committee meeting and was to present the progress made during the year and get HE feedback on this progress The second and third meeting were to discuss how to move forward the ICZM study after the cancellation of the EU tender Based upon these meeting the PMU with the UNDP prepared a letter to the EU which was signed by the HE the Minister explaining the importance of having an ICZM plan for the north coast of Egypt and asking the EU to re reinstate the previously allocated funds for the ICZM and retender the study

description.narrative: Percentage of Shoreline protection agency budget includes coastal stabilization measures designed by the project

comment.narrative: Target is likely to be achieved in SPA is now convinced that soft measures would help in protecting the long reaches of the shoreline 10s of Kilometers that is subjected to erosion SPA has provided good suggestions for the two pilot sites and keen to implement them and maintain them even beyond the project end It is anticipated that once the pilot projects are implemented SPA will keep on monitoring them and provide budget to maintain them at high condition grade

Target is still likely to be achieved in SPA is cofinancing the dike pilot application in Rosetta to Burullus SPA will also monitor the performance of the three implemented alternatives The best alternatives will be implemented by SPA from its own budget

description.narrative: Outcome 1 strengthened Regulatory Framework and Institutional Capacity to improve resilience of coastal settlements and development infrastructure
A comprehensive regulatory and institutional framework for coastal adaptation built around ICZM principles and policies in place

comment.narrative: Existing drafts of ICZM policies but dont account for sea level rise and were never implemented only certain specialized staff has knowledge of concrete adaptation measures Information management systems reflect risks but not climateinduced risks to CZ Existing budgetary allocations are insufficient to meet identified adaptation needs
By end of the project national ICZM plan finalized agency assigned to implement and carry out ME

The Project team has continued to provide technical support to MWRI SPA the EgyptianDutch Advisory Panel Project on Water APP and the EU to finalize the ICZM plan ToR and procurement The tender was announced by the EU in July 2014 The project manager helped in evaluating the received EoIs and the shortlisting process From October 2014 to December 2015 the project manager evaluated with the EU representatives the received offers from 6 contractors Regrettably the requests of the first two shortlisted companies to change key members of the project team with less competent professionals have made their offers non complaint as per the EU procurement rules and accordingly the tender was cancelled in December 2014
Since the ICZM Plan is expected to be the guiding framework for all development and shore protection activities in the North Coast of Egypt at least for the next decade the PMU suggested that part of the funds from the UNDPGEF Climate Change Adaptation Project approx USD 250k is used to initiate the scooping phase of the Plan over the next couple of months This proposal was presented to HE the Minister of Water Resources and Irrigation and the Project Executive Committee members who approved this proposal In mean time the PMU and UNDP will continue to help the Ministry to secure the remaining funds to enable developing the ICZM Plan in the shortest possible time frame

description.narrative: Outcome 2 Strategies and measures that facilitate adaptation to climate change impacts SLR in particular are implemented on the ground in vulnerable coastal areas

Living Shoreline approach adopted to sustain functions and productivity in each of the vulnerable lagoons in the face of sea level rise through preserving existing wetlands and lagoon ecosystems and enhancing their functionality

comment.narrative: To date shore protection has been dominated by hard protection measures lagoon functionality and productivity is at risk due to predominantly nonclimate factors
Nourishment plantstonesand fill placement allow for coast stabilization and ensure that lagoon borders are at least 20 m above lagoons water level

For the first pilot site In Damiatta nourishment of eroding beaches several meetings have been held between the Damiatta Port Authority DPA Shore Protection Authority SPA and Coastal Research Institute CoRI A road map was signed on 21 January 2015 detailing the steps that will be undertaken by each organisation to nourish the eroding breaches near Damiatta with the dredged material from the approach channel of the port In this road map the following was agreed
1 SPA to build sedimentation basins beside the western wall of the port from the project budget
2 DPA to dump the dredged materiel into the sedimentation basins which is estimated to cost LE 60 million to be paid by DPA
3 SPA to transfer the dredged material from the sedimentation basins to nourish the eroding beaches in Damiatta area to be paid from SPAs own budget
4 PMU to explore available options to extract the black sand from the dredged material with relevant organisations in Egypt such as the Nuclear Material Authority NMA A monthly meeting is held with all parties to follow up the progress of the implementation of the road map to date the following progress has been made
1 SPA selected a contractor to build the sedimentation basins and a contract will be signed in July 2015
2 DPA selected a contractor to dredge the approach channel and heshe will dump the material in the sedimentation basin
3 SPA will nourish the eroding breached once 1 and 2 above are on going
4 PMU met with the chairman of NMA and the senior project manager of the black sand project in Egypt It was agreed that more samples will be taken and analysed from the dredged material to ensure economic feasibility of the extraction of the black sand A meeting was also held with a DPA representative to coordinate this process
In addition to the above the PMU has recruited a consultant to assess the economic Feasibility of using the dredged
material from Damietta Port approach channel for sand nourishment This study was undertaken based on a recommendation from the project steering and executive committees

description.narrative: Outcome 3 Knowledge management MA framework and knowledge management system in place Output 31 Guidance documents for GEF and MWRI on climate change adaptation programming in the coastal zones provided
Knowledge and capacity for upscale and replication is in place

comment.narrative: No cases of best practices recorded
At the time of project completion at least 3 examples of best practice generated through the project will be accessible through the ALM

The PMU has reassessed the training needs of the project partners This was done in consultation with them A number of training programs have been proposed to them and to the project executive committee based on this assessment The proposal has been approved by the project executive committee and the project is now in the process of holding those programs

title.narrative: Support to Pension Fund and Fiscal Policy Reform

description.narrative: Support to pension fund reform and fiscal policy and Regulatory environment including mechanisms facilitating development of pro poor policies and services improved.

title.narrative: Strategic Planning Retreat ? Egyptian Ministry of Finance (MOF)

description.narrative: Regulatory environment including mechanisms facilitating development of pro poor policies and services improved.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - policy, planning and administration

A Social Insurance system is integrated with functioning call centers, a website for the social insurance authority. An effective project management is established. Reports and studies are conducted about Policy and technical support provided for the Minister of finance. The PPP approach to government investment projects is monitored.

comment.narrative: MOF is an economic actor in Egypt’s development, but it has played so far a traditional role as a controller of income and expenditures only. The project aims at supportinging MoF as an economic actor in Egypt’s development. MOF’s traditional role of being the government’s financial arm and controller of income and expenditure was extended to being the source of macro-fiscal policy advice to the government during the last cooperation phase with UNDP furthermore, by focusing on the restructuring and automation of the Authority for Social Insurance. The MOF is further increasing its social and economic impact, in line with the role of financial ministries in developed countries.

- Conduct a campaign to introduce VAT to Egyptian Community. - Provide technical support to the minister to perform his functions. - Provide Training for Public and Private Sector and lenders on PPP projects. - Promote PPP projects.

- Led meetings with senior officials at The Egyptian Tax Authority for the preparation of The new VAT law. - Participated in several meetings on the amendments to the VAT law with Vice Minister of Finance on Tax policies and the Egyptian Tax Authority. -The budget estimates for FY 15/16 were revised and updated. The estimates were discussed with Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) to reach a consensus on expected GDP growth and inflation rate. - Participated in the draft of "the Government Program" in collaboration with Ministry of Planning team that focused on the Macroeconomic framework and structural reforms. -Continued to lead communication with IMF mission on Egypt, by providing data, exchanging information, as well as revising and providing feedback on the macroeconomic framework and policy notes prepared by the Egypt mission staff prior to publishing. - Advanced Financial Modeling Course for the Public-Private Partnership Central unit & Public and PPP Satellite Units was offered. - Several national and International conferences were attended to promote PPP projects and many articles about the PPP plan and projects in Egypt were published by local and international printed & electronic media.

- Strategy framework developed to encompass all the initiatives associated with MOF institutional development for the coming 2 year - Pilot Workshop for potential leadership conducted - Strategic Planning Forum conducted - Policy papers developed

- A draft strategy framework for institutional development (IDF) has been designed taking in consideration the results of the strategic planning forums - Second “Strategic planning forum” conducted from 19-21 January 2017. - 4 Action Plans Forums conducted to finalize the strategic plan - MOF continued to lead communication with IMF mission on Egypt, by providing data, exchanging information, as well as revising and providing feedback on the macroeconomic framework and policy notes prepared by the Egypt mission staff prior to publishing - MOF continued to lead the communication with rating agencies to provide updated data on the Egyptian economy, review and comment on draft rating reports on Egypt, as well as arrange annual rating visits

description.narrative: - PMU at MOFP undertakes day to day work - # of CPCs strengthened to advocate abandonment of FGM/C - # of government staff at n’l and local level trained on FGM abandonment strategies - # of governorate strategic plans on FGM abandonment - # of FGM/C cases referred to helpline - # of ministries that mainstreamed FGM/C - Manual integrated into pre service training of MOH - # of regular meetings of steering committee - # of villages declared intention to abandon FGM/C - Increased networks denouncing FGM/C - # of medical doctors trained in anti FGM/C - # of judicial prosecutions against practice of FGM/C - Baseline data on child abuse cases, prevalence of FGM/C - Dissemination of database materials - % of the general public knowledgeable of pro childrearing values including FGM/C - %of the children in the areas of intervention aware and accept of the pro childrearing values (including rejecting FGM/C and corporal punishment) - # of radio & TV spots regularly aired - # of youth trained on organizing edutainment events - # of edutainment events at community level

comment.narrative: - Government Staff trained . - No governorate plan - Work has been taking place in120 villages for which village profiles have been prepared. - 5-10 TV spots and Edutainment events. - A number of Anti-FGM publications have been produced and disseminated. - 91% FGM prevalence rate (age 15-49).

- Strengthen the national anti-FGM legal framework by advocating for amendments to 2008 Law criminalizing FGM
- Develop a policy paper on the loopholes within the 2008 FGM criminalizing law.
- Enhance the capacity of 1,000 of district attorneys and judges on the FGM legal implications and through training forensic medicine doctors.

In 2016, UNDP collaborated with the National Population Council, to strengthen the national anti-FGM legal framework by advocating for amendments to 2008 Law criminalizing FGM, building on a policy paper prepared by a taskforce set up by the UNDP anti-FGM programme and presented to the Ministry of Health highlighting the loopholes in 2008 law (E5,6&7). This was reinforced by the capacity development of over 1,000 of district attorneys and judges on the FGM legal implications and through training forensic medicine doctors. 2016 also witnessed the airing of Enough FGM Campaign to raise awareness of the public on FGM practice.

- Launch the Doctors against FGM initiative
- Conduct TOTs for doctors of the preventive sector
- Issue a book on VAW from a constitutional & legal perspective
- Air anti-FGM TV spots and launch 'Enough FGM' campaign on online news portals.
- Disseminate FGM Curriculum among doctors within the MOHP

Doctors against FGM initiative was launched to integrate a module on harms of FGM & paralegal aspects of engaging in the practice of FGM within Medical Curricula taught in Egyptian medical schools; TOTs were conducted for 85 doctors of preventive sector doctors on FGM messages to disseminate within awareness plans for vaccines campaigns; 25 forensic Medicine doctors were trained on reporting on FGM cases; a book on VAW from a constitutional & legal perspective was issued; anti-FGM TV spots were aired on 18 of most viewed channels; social media campaign ‘Enough FGM’ was launched on 4 online news portals; FGM Curriculum was disseminated among doctors within the MOHP on integrating anti-FGM measures & recognizing role of the national programme as main source of promoting anti-FGM messages.

title.narrative: Strategic Urban Planning for Alexandria City till 2032

description.narrative: Strategic Urban Planning for Alexandria City till 2032
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of country diagnostics carried out to inform policy options on national response to globally agreed development agenda, including with analysis of sustainability and risk resilience
The project seeks to develop a Strategic Urban Plan for Alexandria City to guide development in the city till year 2032, reflecting the Governorate's vision and goals
seat of a first-order administrative division

- A strategic plan for Alexandria city is prepared - A new city boundary is delimited and implemented - A socio-economic plan is activated - Local staff capable of implementing and following-up on plans and actions. - A full network and data exchange system is running between Alexandria regional center and the local planning authority. - An urban management strategy prepared and implemented in Alexandria - An urban information system is running. - Annual city state reports produced. - A Capital Investment plan is produced and adopted by the local authority. - TORs for detailed and action plans produced and used by the local authority

comment.narrative: - The current land use plan and administrative boundaries of Alexandria city is outdated and don’t meet the need for future growth. - The problem of uncontrolled population growth and encroachment of conurbations around the city is increasing. It currently presents a serious challenge to development and social prosperity. - Opportunities for urban development and growth exist but have not been incorporated into strategic planning. - Alexandria regional center is currently connected and networked with GOPP headquarters but the connection is not yet utilized. - Alexandria regional center and local authority’s staff are characterized by low capacity in working within computer-based networked environment, and lack of experience using corporate GIS techniques. - Low capacity at the local level in implementing Strategic Urban Planning (SUP), monitoring or evaluating actions and plans. - Follow-up on plans takes place only on the financial and economic aspects. - Lack of an urban management strategy and implementation mechanisms. - Inefficient land administration system - Lack of a clear M&E system for development follow-up - Low involvement of local communities in monitoring and evaluating the implementation of plans which reduces the sense of ownership among citizens.
- Project extended to deliver pending activities.
Project extended in December 2016 to deliver pending activities.
Prepare the plan of the Matar lake
- The plan for the Matar Lake area was prepared and presented to the governor.

description.narrative: Improving the energy efficiency of lighting and other building appliances (FSP)

title.narrative: Establishing an energy efficiency testing laboratory for Dishwashers
Establishing an energy efficiency testing laboratory for Television sets
Establishing of Energy Efficiency Laboratory for Electric Motors at General Organization For Export & Import Control(G.O.E.I.C)
Pre-Final Evaluation for Energy Efficiency Project

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
Improving the Energy Efficiency of Lighting and Other Building Appliances.The objective of the project is to facilitate a comprehensive market transformation of the Egyptian market
capital of a political entity
Energy - power generation
To improve the energy efficiency of enduse equipment namely building appliances and lighting systems manufactured marketed and used in Egypt
Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

comment.narrative: See the baseline scenario presented in Annex 74

Direct incremental reduction of GHG emissions by 095 million tons of CO2eq by the end of the project and estimated cumulative indirect GHG emission reduction of at least 53 million tons of CO2eq by 2025 on the basis of a conservative policy scenario and a GEF causality factor of 60

The achieved energy savings from this reporting period have been estimated at 477109 MWh equating to 0257 MTons CO2 based on a grid emission factor of 054 tons of CO2 MWh
These savings are calculated for a three months period for the LED lighting program and the street lighting program which is the period starting from the selling date and date of starting of street lighting program up to end of June while for the impact resulting from raising the set point of air conditioners from 16 degree centigrade to 21 degree centigrade the calculated savings are calculated for a 4 month period the savings of the implemented efficient lighting pilot projects have been calculated based on the ending date of each project

description.narrative: The level of compliance of the targeted appliances with the adopted minimum energy performance standards a priori the MEPS to be adopted in Egypt are expected to be in line with those adopted in EU

comment.narrative: From 10 to 50 higher energy consumption depending on the appliance when comparing to the planned MEPS for further details see Annex 74

Over 80 of the appliances sold in the Egyptian market are in compliance with the requirements of those MEPS and labeling schemes that are expected to be in force by the end of the project for further details see Annex 75

The Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy has launched a National initiative for disseminating LED lamps to the residential sector The Ministry contracted a supplier to provide 13 million LED lamps with different wattage 469 watt to be sold on installments added to electricity bills The project provided the Ministry with the technical specifications and testing procedures for tendering purposes
To date more than 18 Million lamps have been sold via Electricity Distribution Companies thus achieving an estimated saving of 40 Million KWh for the 3 month period from the starting selling date up to 30062015
Different government entities are working on reducing electricity consumption as per the Cabinet instructions for all government buildings to reduce electricity consumption by 20
The Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy signed a protocol of cooperation with the Ministry of Local Development and the Arab Organization for Industrialization for LE 23 billion to increase efficiency of street lighting systems to replace the 400 watt and 250 sodium lamps by high efficient 150 and 100 watt sodium lamps respectively The total number of lamps has been estimated at 4 million lamps and the project duration is expected to be around 3 years The first stage is for replacing 05 million lamps up till now 150000 400 watt lamps have been replaced by 150 watt In the mean time the previous program initiated by the Ministry of Electricity and Energy for increasing street lighting efficiency is still ongoing in some governorates but through their own resources with the assistance of the electricity distribution companies this includes CFLs 85125 watt replacing 100 and150 watt sodium lamps with electronic ballast Meanwhile The New Urban Communities Authority NUCA announced issuing a contract for LE 70 million to change all street lighting systems in the new cities to LED systems
Ministry of Tourism has announced an innovative lending program offering loans to hotels for replacing lighting systems and installing solar water heaters that will be settled based on the occupancy rate in the hotel
Ministry of Industry has released a Ministerial decree to activate MEPS for fans and dishwashers
Egyptian Organization for Standardization EOS activated in cooperation with other key relevant authorities the new national S L programme enforcement mechanism to confirm the compliance of the issued labels with the developed MEPS These labels are released based on the testing results performed at NREAs labs established in the first phase of the project
Based on the results of the Energy Efficiency tests NREA and the issued labels from EOS Mmost of the released labels are rated either A or B except for the air conditioners which are rated CDE but still an improvement when compared to previous results showing a lower rate of compliance where some of the tested units were not complying with the MEPS
Meanwhile the level of efficiency of these appliances have improved comparing to the last year levels
The awareness campaign that has been launched last year for increasing public awareness of energy efficiency through the young students will continue this year but on a larger scale to cover 10 of the Egyptian governorates through the cooperation with the NGOs working with the Small Grants Program of GEF and the Consumer Agency Protection

description.narrative: A comprehensive SL scheme for building appliances developed and effectively implemented matching international and regional best policy and technology practices and with energy efficiency requirements set at a level where cost effectiveness is proven
The share of noncompliant products

comment.narrative: not given
Fewer than 10 of all the random samples tested at the end of the project show noncompliance

Based on the test results from NREA testing laboratories and issued labels from EOS the rate of compliance with the minimum energy performance standards MEPS has increased 97 for refrigerators 100 for the electric water heaters 100 for automatic washing machines86 for split air conditioners
Meanwhile the level of efficiency for this reporting period has improved when compared to last year figures
For the refrigerators 55 are rated A the highest energy efficiency rating up from 43 last year
For washing machines 97 are rated A up from 94 last year For electric water heaters 90 are rated A up from 71 last year
As for the air conditioners although the level of compliance has increased but still the efficiency is low

description.narrative: The status and content of the legal and regulatory acts and the agreed implementation arrangements dealing with appliance minimum energy performance standards MEPS labeling schemes and their enforcement

comment.narrative: Minimum energy performance standards andor labeling schemes developed and adopted for 5 appliances CFLs refrigeratorsfreezers washing machines airconditioners and electric water heaters but not adequately enforced and monitored yet

Strengthened implementation enforcement and market monitoring of the SL schemes adopted for the first five appliances to cover both import and local production as demonstrated by verified annual statistics on the sale of the different appliances sold as per the different energy classes
Expanded SL implementation enforcement and market monitoring schemes formally adopted for new appliances consisting of TVs and their accessories information and communication appliances ICT standby power external power supply EPS electric fans and electric motors as per the schedule presented in Annex 75

The project supports Egyptian Organization for Standardization in developing MEPS for fans and dish washers and the Ministerial decree for enforcement has been issued as well as the informative labels for the two appliances
Contract was signed with a supplier to establish a testing laboratory for fans in Egyptian Organization for Standards EOS and tendering process for establishing testing labs for dishwaters and pumps is still ongoing
The project is supporting EOS in developing the MEPS for household appliances where the final draft has been prepared for TVs and water pumps and in process for the ovens compressors and inverter air conditioners
A national consulting firm was contracted to conduct a survey and assessment of household appliances energy consumption patterns First draft of the report is submitted including preliminary analysis of survey data of 5000 samples in 5 governorates Cairo Alexandria Giza Ismalyia and Menya The report analyzed the degree of saturation for the different appliances but some data were not easily obtained mainly the power consumption and the duration of use per month These issues will be dealt with in the final report which will also include detailed analysis of the consumption patterns
The EE unit at EOS initiated the new SL monitoring mechanism that has been developed for issuing the labels that will have a serial number and a barcode stored in a data base at EOS to allow authorized inspecting authorities to verify the information on the label The software has been developed and the project has supplied EOS and Consumer Protection Agency with four hand held units to inspect the barcodes in the market Over the last 6 month period EOS issued 40 labels for the refrigerators 24 rated A and 16 rated B 31 labels for deep freezers 11 A and 13B Electric water heaters 21 labels 19A1B and 1E 2 washing machines rated A6 air conditioner window type rated E 89 split units 10 rated C 11 rated Dand 68 rated E16 CFLs 14 rated A and 2 rated B
Some problems were met when using the software the project will provide a new version of the software
The project completed a six months public awareness campaign launched last year through the young volunteers and will initiated again this year Moreover the project has signed a memorandum of understanding with the GEF Small Grant Program to extend the awareness activities in 10 governorates with the assistance of the NGOs working with the GEF SGP and in coordination with the Consumer Protection Agency
The project signed an MOU with Consumer Protection Agency to jointly implement an awareness campaign on the SL programme and ensure more involvement of the civil society in monitoring the energy labels for home appliances and verifying the information on the EE labels

description.narrative: Accelerated growth of the EE lighting market in Egypt in line with the Global UNEPUNDP EE Lighting initiative
Total volume or the market share of the CFLs and other EE lighting appliances in Egypt

comment.narrative:
CFLs No new MEPS adopted annual sale of 25 million CFLs reached by 2015 as a result of a continuing natural growth
LFLs and HIDs No new EE requirements formally adopted and reflected in public procurement processes

CFLs Annual sale of 35 million CFLs reached by 2015 resulting from projects market promotion activities new MEPS adopted for completely phasing out incandescent light bulbs as per the schedule elaborated in Annex 75
LFLs and HIDs street Lighting The second set of EU consistent EE requirements have entered into force they are reflected in the technical specifications for public procurement and less than 10 of the random samples tested show noncompliance

The project has implemented more than 15 energy efficiency lighting pilot projects supported by technical assistanceaudit techno economic feasibility study specifications list of qualified suppliers published also on the web site preparation of tender documents in addition to financial contribution varying between 50 of the total cost for public buildings and 25 for private sector buildings that was shared equally with funds from the UNDP Regional Arab Climate Resilience Initiative ACRI Projects were implemented in different types of buildings including governmental buildings administration building bank hotels library street lighting of residential compounds retail shop etc In addition the project is providing technical assistance with no financial contribution to a number of other entities including large chain of supermarkets in Egypt and some other private sector facilities
Press releases for the implemented projects are issued in different newspapers announcing the projects results to increase general awareness Case studies and promotional brochures are under preparation to document the savings that varied between 2540 of the total electricity bill and a payback period of between six months and one year in most buildings Brochures will be distributed in awareness seminars directed to targeted groups to advocate for replication at the National level
Some of projects beneficiaries have decided to replicate the projects in their facilities mainly the CIB bank Marriott hotels the New Urban Communities Authority of the Ministry of Housing
The project organized three training courses on Auditing and Energy Efficiency Lighting in buildings attended by 73 engineers from various Ministries The project in cooperation with the Housing and Building Research Center has organized 4 training courses on the Energy Efficiency street lighting code The courses were attended by 138 trainees from all relevant authorities
A special training course for design and implementation of lighting projects in hotels was jointly funded by EU MED ENEC Project in cooperation with the Ministry of Tourism and conducted by an international consultant The project sponsored a visit for the President of the Chinese National Lighting Testing Center NLTC to lecture in the training workshop
The project supported EOS to develop specifications for different types of LED lighting lamps
The National Consulting firm contracted to evaluate the street lighting situation in Egypt has assessed the situation and evaluated achievements and draw backs of the energy efficiency implemented street lighting project Outputs and recommendations of the study will be shared with senior officials of the Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy
A simplified version of the Energy efficiency street lighting code has been prepared by the consultant and will be handed to local authorities and municipalities engineers
A database model has also been developed to enable model users testing different options for street lighting energy efficiency projects needed investments and expected savings
Upon formal request from the New Urban Communities Authority the project has recruited a specialized international consultant to provide technical assistance for the implementation of a pilot project for PVLED street lighting project in a six Km desert road Conceptual design as well as the bidding documents have been prepared On job training has also been provided by the consultant
Within the memorandum of understanding signed with the Energy Efficiency Unit EEU of the Cabinet of Ministers more than 35 energy audits were conducted by the project in different government buildings where transformation to efficient lighting was co funded by the EEU

description.narrative: Sustained project results
The level of information available for adaptive management and for measuring the impact of the project

comment.narrative: Insufficient information for adaptive management and for measuring the impact of the project
Annually updated information on the sale of each targeted appliance as per its energy performance class and the level of compliance with the adopted standards and regulations available

The results of the conducted survey on the impact of the awareness programs have been used as a baseline when compared to the outputs of the campaigns organized by the project through the young students this revealed that the knowledge on energy efficiency measures has improved and the satisfaction of the customers on the way of getting the information through direct contacts rather than media programs
The market monitoring mechanism has provided the information on the entities that possess the scattered data relating to the annual market size of home appliances and lampsaccordingly the project contacted the identified entities to collect market size data of lighting and home appliances but the response was not very positive and still information was not sufficient to establish the data base nor to evaluate the savings from improving the level of efficiency based on the market size and not on tested samples at the energy efficiency testing laboratories which is giving just an indication but not a level of achieved savings

description.narrative: The status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability

comment.narrative: Insufficient institutional mechanisms in place to ensure sustainability of project results
Sustained institutional and financial mechanisms in place to promote the market for EE appliances and related market monitoring

The project sustainability will be achieved through the different Energy Efficiency departments that have been established in the Ministry with the support of the World Bank in the Egyptian Electricity Holding Company and the units that have been created at the level of the 9 electricity distribution companies
The project activities will be sustained through one of the items included in the Electricity law on Energy Efficiency and which has already been ratified
The project will be sustained through the different MEPS that have developed for the home appliances and the testing laboratories established at the New and Renewable Energy Authority and the Egyptian Organization for Standards
Sustainability will be achieved through the effective activation of the developed Market Monitoring System that has been developed after resolving the problems encountered and with cooperation with the different relevant authorities responsible of monitoring the Standards and Labeling Program
Sustainability will also be achieved through the Loan Guarantee Mechanism that will be sustained even after the project termination as the agreement is signed between the Loan Guarantee Company and the Egyptian Electricity Holding Company The total issued guarantees have reached 30 Million LE for 84 projects the total expired guarantees 23 Million LE for 51 projects and the total outstanding guarantees 6690 Million LE for 33 projects and is trying to leverage the budget of the loan guarantee program to enable more projects implementation

- Created an Egyptian Foundation for Innovation Brand Equity. - Launched a stream of regular Egyptian Investment Fairs / Events throughout 2013. - Number of curriculum for Innovation courses developed. - Number of success stories of innovative Egyptians as ICT role models.

comment.narrative: - Lack of policies and institutions involved in the promotion of innovation brand equity in Egypt. - Egypt is already engaged in a large number of events, however ICT innovation culture is still inadequately covered by Egypt. - Lack of specialized courses among Egyptian Universities and business schools focused on patenting, licensing and intellectual property. - Lack of strategies to showcase the success of ICT initiatives in Egypt.

1) InnovEgypt Program is an undergraduate unique program in the area of innovation and entrepreneurship directed to university students in ICT specializations who are aspiring to be future innovators and entrepreneurs, either through establishing their own innovative start-ups or through manifesting skills that are highly required by local and multinational companies. targets: 18 ± 2 Number of Rounds 1080 ± 90 Number of Certified Trainees 24 ± 2 Number of New Certified Trainers
2)Funding for fabrication of electronic chips for graduation projects of Egyptian universities - 2 round of research or industrial projects
3) As part of our role to build the capacity of school students and increase awareness of the concept of creativity through the application and training. And in order to broaden participation of the public schools’ students in the competition to support the development of technical and innovation skills. Under this project, four enterprises in Egypt, namely Cairo Foam, MOG, FRESH and SECC, will phase-out the use of HCFC-141b in its PU insulation foam production. The project includes either replacement of the foam dispensers, or retrofitting IMPACT OF THE PROJECT ON COUNTRY’S MONTREAL PROTOCOL OBLIGATIONS: This project eliminates 37, 4 t ODP (340 t HCFC-141b) which will contribute to Egypt’s efforts to fulfill its commitments under the Montreal Protocol and its amendments. Egypt is a Party to the Vienna Convention and the Montreal Protocol. It also ratified the London,Copenhagen and Montreal am

title.narrative: Enhancing Access to Knowledge for Development

description.narrative: The project is to build on the success achieved by “Empowering and Connecting the Community though ICT and Egypt’s Emergence as a Regional Digital Hub” project.
This output covers proposed work related to new technological trends as Cloud Computing, Data Centres, Integrated Solutions, and Web 2.0 as top priorities in the ICT agenda.“
capital of a political entity

This is a core project that supports the whole ICT sector and focuses on the need to use the latest technology to positively impact the quality of life and welfare of human beings. It fosters implementing state-of-the art initiatives to serve Egyptian citizens and sustainable human development. The project supports the creation of innovative solutions and applications and maximizing ICT outsourcing services and exports to increase the GDP. Through supporting engaging in regional and international activities, it helps position and brand Egypt’s ICT competitive edge in the global arena. The project has an overarching output for “Building Egypt’s Knowledge Society to achieve socio-economic development and reduce human poverty” through five outputs related to upgrading the ICT Infrastructure; developing ICT polices, strategies and indicators; modernizing and improving life of citizens; providing community services outreach and training; and supporting knowledge sharing and international relations.

comment.narrative: The project targets building the knowledge society and having ICT integrated in all aspects of life. The cooperation between MCIT and UNDP focused on four main key successes: developing the capacity of the Ministry through provision of national and international technical expertise and recruitment of high caliber project managers, project staff and consultants required for implementing the national strategy; conducting international studies and going through UNDP international bidding process for purchasing of services; engaging in regional and international ICT activities and events at which Egypt’s share best practices, leads the regional agenda, and partners with international organizations which could be applied on infrastructure & policies levels; and carrying-out South-South Cooperation activities

The project has an overarching output for “Building Egypt’s Knowledge Society to achieve socio-economic development and reduce human poverty” through five outputs related to upgrading the ICT Infrastructure; developing ICT polices, strategies and indicators; modernizing and improving life of citizens; providing community services outreach and training; and supporting knowledge sharing and international relations.
Performance:
The project supported ICT sector to move with steady steps towards building the knowledge society in spite of all the challenges facing the country. ICT GDP at fixed prices reached 13.8 billion EGP in 3rd Q of Y 2015/2016 realizing a growth rate of about 5.2% compared to the equivalent quarter in 2014/2015, which generated 13.13 billion EGP of value. ICT sector contributed by 3.1% in the real GDP of the country in 3rd Q of Y 2015/2016, which exceeded its contribution to the GDP that of the equivalent 3rd Q of Y 2014/2015, which was around 3% of the GDP. The number of ADSL subscriptions reached 4.00 million subscriptions by the end of January - March 2016 compared to 3.27 million subscriptions at the end of January - March 2015 with an annual change rate 22.5%. The number of mobile internet subscriptions reached 25.88 million subscriptions by the end of January - March 2016 compared to 23.31 million subscriptions at the end of January - March 2015 with an annual change rate 20.80%. (Information Center, August 2016).

 Hosted Africa 2016 forum under the patronage of the President and the umbrella of the AU, Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, February 2016. This African international business forum shed light on investment opportunities available in Egypt and Africa to stimulate the private sector to increase its investments in many areas, especially in the fields of energy, ICTs, etc..
 Hosted Tanzania mission of six ICT ToTs in Caioro in Feb. 2016 who received integrated training program on cybersecurity and CERTs management, and a course on PKI.. This followed Egypt's strategy to strengthen cooperation with the African continent and underlined its leading ICT role in Africa. It came as a continuation of the 2015 training. The project covered the cost of the training, airline tickets, full accommodation, internal transportation and site seeing tour totaling EGP 64,000
 Sponsored participation in 28th IoI, annual international informatics competition for youngsters, that took place in Kazan, Russia, August 2016. Coved registration and visa fees, airline tickets, DSA for one week-stay, and a unified special uniform. The team achieved a bronze medal in this competition.

-Inclusion and empowerment of all the Egyptian citizens and empowering vulnerable people
-ICT to reach all areas to avail training opportunities and capacity building to fit the labor force and reduce poverty

The Project provides Community Services Outreach and Training through fostering sustainable human development of all Citizens including PWDs all over Egypt, extending training facilities especially in poor and remote deprived areas to make youth fit the labour market. The Project supports improving gender equality and women’s empowerment through availing the same equal training opportunities for males and females. The issues of gender inequalities and empowering women were monitored through statistics conducted by MCIT Information Center especially for number of female and male students taking training skills (basic ICT training as ICDL Program), or professional training provided by ITI and NTI. The proportion of students, graduates, and post-graduates by gender was monitored and published.
Due care has continuously been given to ICT for Girls and Women in Egypt to benefit from their capabilities and help them overcome the challenges they had faced on both the educational and career levels. Proportion of students, graduates, and post-graduates by gender with IT specialty or Communication specialty have been traced to ensure equal opportunities provided for empowering girls and young women and adjust the ration if required. This should help women to enter the field of ICT whether through education, training or employment The Project ensured providing equal training opportunities to students, fresh graduates, and post-graduates (females and males). It targeted making available all the resources and developing the skills and knowledge at an affordable and flexible way for meeting the needs of the future. The Projects supported boosting the skills and knowledge of graduates who might lack the ICT knowledge needed for the marketplace despite their specialized education. The rate of employment is expected to increase dramatically through the acquisition of ICT knowledge and skills. The idea is not in transforming youth into computer programmers, but in enhanci

capital of a political entity

The proposed project is designed in accordance with Egypt National Action Plan (2011/2012) as it directly contributes to three central pillars of the plan out of the seven: “ On the first hand, the first output is supposed to enable the environment for business and investment, as it will provide some facilities to Small/Micro and Medium enterprises. On the other hand, the second output that deals with building capacities is to fulfil the axes of both citizenship participation, as well as Human Development.
Through the project pillars; local economic development and social empowerment, the project will facilitate and accelerate development by focusing on citizens and their needs. The Third Phase of the project aims to improve achieving human development conditions (education and health, social awareness) as well as enforcing a healthy competitive environment for business and entrepreneurship efforts. This will improve the Egyptian economy through depending on the private sector rather than the public sector.

comment.narrative: ICT-TF, through phase III, will focus on job creation while supporting the creation of a healthy competitive environment for micro, small and medium enterprises as a way to fight poverty. It will also focus on improving education especially that of disabled and vocational students. The Egypt ICT-TF will also focus on health through a capacity building sessions for rural doctors and a remote diagnosis system (especially for children) to improve health systems in rural areas in Egypt. Last but not the least, through raising awareness on green ICT and developing a portal for best agriculture practices (Aradina.net), Egypt ICT-TF will endorse a green and best resource usage culture.
Integrated ICT for Development

• Enhance the public health using the telemedicine solution • Provide telemedicine labs to 2 local health NGOs in Nubia • Upgrade the telemedicine solution CU.telemed.org.eg • Equip ElQasr El Aini hospital with the telemedicine unit • Test the system in Nubia and El Kharga Oasis • Train 58 MSMEs on business development • Build the capacity of 122 MSMEs on e-marketing and selling skills • Conduct 4 women empowerment awareness sessions and 20 educational sessions for teachers • Build the capacity of 100 women on klim, arjoun and sewing skills • Plan for phase II in cooperation with Aswan Government

comment.narrative: This project is part of Egypt's Post commitment to modernizing its service to citizens and to help better delivery of its services to mainly the poor whom are considered to be the majority in need for a better quality of life. The project aims to obtain its goals by improving EP's internal structure, renovating its postal offices, facilitating its financial services delivery in the best manner and attaining customer satisfaction.

Recruit the right candidates to develop the organisational structure. / design and plan for proper training schemes to enhance the business efficiency / Develop proper and effective information systems.

1- Many gaps in the structure was filled in with the proper candidates such as Director of Human Resources; Director of Marketing; CFO, CCO; Business Development Manager; Print-House Director; Customer Service Director. 2- Egypt Post re- branding Identity project took place (Celebrating 150 Anniversary), to change/improve the image of the institution, it was accomplished through a rigorous campaign of ads and publications among the TV, Radio, everywhere: street banners, brochures, etc.... It happened upon blending tradition of over 150 years’ business in the creation of the Postal Authority and the issuance of the first postage stamp and modernity of business development and modernization of the mechanisms of actions and the expansion of service delivery. This rebranding project also restored the spirit of belonging and self-importance to all employees. It addressed and attracted new segments of customers to Egypt Post and it also emphasised important role of Egypt Post regionally. 3- Development and implementation of training sessions and studies relevant to the Financial Retail & Saving Sectors the following took place 4- Registered Egypt Post with FATCA (Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act) in order to be compliant. 5- A unified internal procedures for the operations of the Universal Tellers was developed. Subject procedures merge all transactions (financial & non- financial transactions) performed within the branches or offices into one document. The document includes detailed sequence of the operations of all the products and identifying the role of all stockholders. It also highlight the major segregation of duties and control issues. The document has been approved by most of the authorized persons and will be circulated to all branches upon signing off from all the concerned parties. 6- Participation with the Audit & Compliance team in meetings aimed at assessing the proposed new systems or programs for AML (anti-Money L

Provide skills development to at least 500 people &create at least 190 new jobs in areas of manufacturing (handicrafts, ready-made garments, etc.), sustainable agri&basic services.

UNDP achieved significant progress in enhancing skills of young people&providing access to job opportunities especially women&youth applying an area-based innovative&integrated development approach in Upper Egypt through Egypt Network for Integrated Development (ENID) project. UNDP provided skills development to 537 people &created 195 new jobs in areas of manufacturing (handicrafts, ready-made garments, etc.), sustainable agri&basic services. 75% of beneficiaries were women & majority youth aged 18-35. ENID operated in more than 45 villages in Upper EGY empowering directly/indirectly more than 10,000 lives & expanded partnership w/11 ministries, 3 governorates& more than 50 local NGOs to promote its integrated approaches.

Implemented by The Operational Unit for Development Assistance (OUDA), the SDS established a Cairo South-South Development Academy to share countries’ development experiences based on common interests and provide shared platforms of learning and knowledge exchange among those facing similar development challenges. The Academy is a chapter of the Global South-South Development network managed by the UN Office for South-South Cooperation (UNOSSC) and a vital node of the GSSD Expo.

comment.narrative: Website active, dynamic portal under construction. Communication package developed: logo, social media pages active UNOSSC Portal landing page developed for SSDA
in progress
The documented solutions target these population groups: the poor, women, female-headed households, People with disabilities and youth

CSSDA targets solution providers across the country. Solution providers range from government institutions, corporate CSR projects, entrepreneurial solutions, solutions provided by international development organization and civil society. The documented solutions fall under the two thematic areas mentioned above; Thematic focus area #1: Innovation for Development considering the use of ICT tools to overcome development challenges. Egypt is full of ICT for development innovative solutions that deserve to be showcased and have yet to receive the attention they deserve; This can be in various domains such as: health, education, poverty eradication, socio-economic development, etc. Thematic focus area #2: Sustainable Management of Water Resources (Including recycling and desalinization solutions). The academy documents solutions that fall within the thematic focus areas and under the following domains: education, poverty eradication, employment, gender equality, opportunities for people with disabilities and social entrepreneurship with the aim of replicating the sustainable development solution that have a proven impact on society.
The documented solutions target these population groups: the poor, women, female-headed households, and youth.
- The poor, women, and female-headed households’ groups are represented in the documentation of the Egypt Network for Integrated Development (ENID).
- The Youth group is represented in the documentations of Kenana Online, Youth Employment Generation projects, Masr Works, Bassita, and the Information Technology Institute.
- Pepole with disabilities group is represented in the documentations of Tawasol Systems and Skills and Jobs for people with disabilities.

comment.narrative: The project main aim is to assist in the formulation of regulatory strategies that promote and seek to ensure equal access to various ICT based services, which in turn has spill-over effects in strengthening equal and equitable access to telecommunications services for the Egyptian populace. This will be in accordance with the national priority highlighted in the United Nations current Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF) 2013-2017 which that maintains that “Government is operating with efficient and adequately resourced mechanisms of awareness creation, equitable targeting, delivering and monitoring of social protection services and access to adequate and affordable housing for children, young people, rural women, elderly and other vulnerable groups.”
Hold at least one ICT regulatory event

Under the Auspices of H.E. President Abdel Fatah El Sisi, Egypt represented in the National Telecommunication Regulatory Authority (NTRA) hosted this year’s ITU’s Global Symposium for Regulators (GSR) which is the world’s pre-eminent ICT regulatory event, attracting experts from all corners of the world. It was officially chaired by H. E. Yasser ElKady, Egypt’s Minister of Communications and Information Technology and Chairman of NTRA Board of Directors, and an opening speech given by ITU Secretary-General Houlin Zhao.
